Visualization (scarlet.display)¶

It is often useful to visualize deblending results in matplotlib or similar plotting software. scarlet includes several convenience methods to scale flux and convert multiband image data into RGB arrays.

Reference/API¶

class scarlet.display.Asinh(vmin=None, vmax=None, img=None, Q=10, clip=False)[source]¶

Use arcsinh to map image intensities in matplotlib

asinh(value)[source]¶

Calculate asinh with the appropriate stretching

get_range()[source]¶

Get the possible range for a given vmin and vmax

inverse(value)[source]¶

Invert the mapping

This is used to undo the mapping, for example matplotlib uses this to generate the values in the colorbar.

scaled()[source]¶

Have vmax and vmin been set?

scarlet.display.img_to_rgb(img, norm=None, fill_value=0, filter_indices=None)[source]¶

Convert an image array into an RGB image array

img: array_like
This should be an array with dimensions (bands, height, width).
norm: matplotlib.colors.Normalize, default=`None`
Normalization to use for colormap scaling. The default is None, which uses a linear scaling. This is expected to be class that inherits from matplotlib.colors.Normalize, which adjusts the scale of the input image to the range [0,1].
fill_value: float, default=`0`
Value to use for any masked pixels.
filter_indices: list, default=`None`
Order of the filters to convert to RGB. Since typically img is ordered from bluest to reddest colors, if filter_indices is None a default value of [2,1,0] is used, inverting the order to properly match the reddest color to R.
rgb: numpy array with dtype uint8
RGB image
